item.title: Three Ways I Think Frameworks are Good (actually)
item.description: A recent conversation with my friend Dr Jon Sykes sparked some thoughts about where frameworks derive their value. The conversation started with a question: is the benefit of frameworks really just that they create a shared language? We were discussing my review of Chapter 2 of “How Big Things Get Done” and examining the framework that is emerging from my reading so far. This led us to identify three distinct sources of value in frameworks.

item.title: Is Psychology or Politics Behind Project Failures?
item.description: A key theme from Chapter 2 of “How Big Things Get Done” is that while we know we should think slowly and act fast, people often do the exact opposite. The chapter explores the psychological and political forces driving this behaviour.

item.title: Think Slow, Act Fast: The Paradox of Project Planning
item.description: In the book How Big Things Get Done, Bent Flyvbjerg and Dan Gardner presented an analysis of why large projects fail to meet their objectives. As someone who has witnessed the ups and downs of loads of projects, I’m very curious to learn what we can do better.

item.title: Things I Think I Think
item.description:
I want to use this blog to think, learn, and work in public..

I chose this name because I want to be able to write stuff without having to definitely commit forever to holding whatever ideas I have shared. Therefore these posts are just things I think I think.
